ElementDescription: The NDAR Global Unique Identifier (GUID) for research subject
Subject ID how it's defined in lab/project
Date on which the interview/genetic test/sampling/imaging/biospecimen was completed. MM/DD/YYYY
Age in months at the time of the interview/test/sampling/imaging.
Notes: Age is rounded to chronological month. If the research participant is 15-days-old at time of interview, the appropriate value would be 0 months. If the participant is 16-days-old, the value would be 1 month.

ElementDescription: Sex of subject at birth
Notes: M = Male; F = Female; O=Other; NR = Not reported

ElementDescription: Visit name
Notes: e.g., Baseline, 6-Month Follow Up, Year 2, Daily

ElementDescription: MetaTrial Visit ID
Notes: System variable: unique code for each type of visit -use to merge files

ElementDescription: Regarding eating, which best describes (S) usual performance?
Notes: 0 = Usually or always was fed by someone else; 1 = Used fingers to eat; 2 = Used a fork or spoon, but not a knife, to eat; 3 = Ate without physical help, and used a knife

ElementDescription: Regarding walking (or getting around in a wheelchair), which best describes his/her usual performance?
Notes: 0 = Required physical help to walk or transfer; 1 = Transferred from bed to chair without help; 2 = Mobile across a room without physica help; 3 = Mobile outside of home without physical help

ElementDescription: Regarding bowel and bladder function
Notes: 0 = Needed physical help, and was usually incontinent; 1 = Needed physical help, and was usually continent; 2 = Needed supervision, but no physical help; 3 = Did everything necessary without supervision or help

ElementDescription: Regarding bathing, which best describes his/her usual performance?
Notes:
0 = Needed to be bathed completely;
1 = Needed minor physical help (e.g., washing hair) to bathe completely; 2 = No physical help, but needed supervision/reminders to bathe completely; 3 = Bathed without reminding or physical help

ElementDescription: Regarding grooming, which best describes his/her optimal performance
Notes: 0 = Needed help for grooming of hair, face, hands, and fingernails; 1 = Kept face and hands clean without physical help; 2 = Brushed or combed hair without physical help; 3 = Cleaned and cut fingernails without physical help

ElementDescription: Regarding dressing, did subject select his/her first set of clothes for the day?
Which best describes his/her usual performance?
Notes: 1 = With physical help; 2 = With supervision; 3 = Without supervision or help

ElementDescription: Regarding physically getting dressed, which best describes his/her usual performance?
Notes: 0 = Always need help, regardless of the type of clothing; 1 = Dressed without help if clothes needed no fastening or buttoning; 2 = Needed physical help only for buttons, clasps, or shoelaces; 3 = Dressed completely with supervision, but without physical help; 4 = Dressed completely without supervision or physical help

ElementDescription: Did subject use a telephone?
Which best describes his/her highest level of performance?
Notes: 1 = Did not answer the phone, but spoke when put on the line; 2 = Answered the phone; did not make calls; 3 = Made calls only to well-known numbers, by using directory or list; 4 = Made calls only to well-known numbers, without referring to a directory or list; 5 = Made calls after looking in white or yellow pages, or by dialing directory assisstance

ElementDescription: Did subject watch television?
Did subject usually select or ask for different programs or his/her favorite show?
Did subject usually talk about the content of a program while watching it?
Did subject talk about the content of a program within a day (24 hours) after watching it?
Did subject ever appear to pay attention to conversation or small talk for at least 5 minutes?
Which best describes his/her usual degree of participation?
Notes: 1 = Rarely or never spoke; 2 = Usually said things that were not related to the topic; 3 = Usually said things that were related to the topice

ElementDescription: Did subject clear the dishes from the table after a meal or snack?
Which best describes how he/she usually performed?
Notes: 1 = With physical help; 2 = With supervision; 3 = Without supervision or help

ElementDescription: Which best describes how he/she usually performed?
Notes: 1 = With physical help; 2 = With supervision; 3 = Without supervision or help

ElementDescription: Did subject obtain a hot or cold beverage for him/herself?
Which best describes his/her highest level of performance?
Notes: 1 = Obtained a cold beverage, usually without physical help; 2 = Made a hot beverage, usually if someone else heated the water; 3 = Made a hot beverage, usually without physical help

ElementDescription: Did subject make him/herself a meal or snack at home?
Which best describes his/her highest level of food preperation?
Notes: 1 = Obtained food on his/her own, without mixing or cooking it; 2 = Mixed or combined food items for a meal or snack, without cooking or microwaving; 3 = Cooked or microwaved food, with extensive help; 4 = Cooked or microwaved food, with little or no help

ElementDescription: Did the subject dispose of garbage or litter in an appropriate place or container at home?
Whch best describes how he/she usually performs?
Notes: 1 = With physical help; 2 = With supervision; 3 = Without supervision or help

ElementDescription: Did subject get around (or travel) outside of his/her home?
Which best describes his/her optimal performance
Notes: 1 = Only with physical help, regardless of the trip; 2 = Only when accopmanied and supervised, regardless of the trip; 3 = Alone, but remained within 1 mile of home; 4 = Alone, went at least 1 mile away from home

ElementDescription: Did subject ever go shopping?
Which best describes how subject usually selects items?
Notes: 1 = Not at all, or selected mainly random or inappropriate items; 2 = With some supervision or physical help; 3 = Without supervision or physical help

ElementDescription: Did subject usually pay for items without supervision or physical help?
Did subject keep appointments or meetings with other people, such as relatives, a doctor, the hairdresser, etc.?
Which best describes his/her awareness of the meeting ahead of time?
Notes: 1 = Usually did not remember, in spite of verbal reminders on the day; 2 = Only remembered the appointment after verbal reminders on the day; 3 = Usually remembered, may have needed written reminders

ElementDescription: Was subject ever left on his/her own?
Notes: 0 = No; 1 = Yes; 8 = S is institutionalized; 9 = Don't Know

ElementDescription: Was subject left away from home, for 15 minutes or longer, during the day?
Was subject left at home, for an hour or linger, during the day?
Was subject left at home, for less than an hour, during the day?
Did subject talk about current events?
Did subject talk about events that he/she heard or read about or saw on TV but did not take part of it?
Did subject talk about events that took part outside the home involving family, friends, or neighbors?
Did subject read a magazine, newspaper, or book for more than 5 minutes at a time?
Did subject usually talk about details of what he/she read while or shortly (<1 hour) after reading?
Did subject usually talk about what he'she read 1 hour or longer after reading
Did subject ever write things down?
Which best describes the most complicated things that he/she wrote?
Notes: 1 = His/her signature or name; 2 = Short notes or messages that other people understood; 3 = Letters or long notes that other people understood

ElementDescription: Did subject perform a pastime, hobby or game?
card or board games
bingo
musical instrument
reading
tennis
crosswords
knitting
gardening
workshop
art
sewing
golf
fishing
other
Did subject perform hobbies/pastime only at day care?
How did subject usually perform his/her most common pastimes?
Notes: 1 = With physical help; 2 = With supervision; 3 = Without supervision or help

ElementDescription: In the past 4 weeks, did subject use a household applicance to do chores?
washer?
dishwasher
range
dryer
toaster
microwave
vacuum
toaster oven
food processor
other
For the most commonly used appliances, which best describes how the subject usually used them?
Notes: 1 = With physical help; 2 = With supervision, but no physical help; 3 = Without help, but operated only on/off controls; 4 = Without help, operating more than on-off controls if needed

ElementDescription: Total score
Number of Don't Know responses in ADL
Numeric Visit Number
Notes: -1.5 = Pre-Screening; -1 = Screening; 0 = Baseline; ## = Visit ## (from 1 to 10); Whole numbers = standard monthly visits; #.001 - #.009 = Unscheduled; #.1 = End of Phase 1; #.2 = End of Phase 2; #.3 = End of Phase 3; #.4 = End of Open Choice Phase; #.5 = End of Study; #.6 = Genetic Analysis; 1000=all visits

ElementDescription: Current Phase. Phase patient was in at the time of the assessment Phase 4 refers to the follow-up phase.
ValueRange: Pre-Rand; Phase 1/1A; Phase 2; Phase 3; Phase 4; Phase 1B; Open-Choice Phase; Screening; Phase 1

ElementDescription: ADCS Total Score
Flag Last Phase 1/1A Visit
Notes: 1=Yes for all records meeting this criteria

ElementDescription: Flag Baseline Phase 1/1A Visit
Notes: 1=Yes for all records meeting this criteria

ElementDescription: Baseline Total Score
Changed from Baseline ADAS Total Score

ElementDescription: In the past year, have you been involved in sports or athletics?
What sports and/or athletics have you been involved in in the past year?

What percentage of these sports/athletics in the past year have been organized (e.g., school varsity, club, or intramural teams; community team; class) as opposed to unorganized (e.g., local pick-up game; solitary running or cycling)?
Notes: Percentage of sports/athletics that were organized.

ElementDescription: In the past month, have you been involved in sports or athletics?

Notes: Percentage of sports/athletics that were organized.
